awd_titl_txt: Build, Understand, & Tune Interventions that Cumulate to Real Impact
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Pittsburgh has received an NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Education and Human Resources Design and Development tier award to bring together a highly interdisciplinary team to study a suite of instructional, cognitive-skill, and social/motivational interventions that have been demonstrated to produce large improvements in learning in the context of introductory STEM courses.  This research is significant because it will allow us to understand which interventions produce long-term positive outcomes, whether these interventions combine negatively or synergistically within and across courses, and the types of situations or groups of students for which they are most effective. 

The project team consists of four Discipline-Based Education Research scientists (biology, chemistry, physics, and psychology), three learning scientists with expertise in social/motivational, cognitive skills or active STEM learning techniques, and a learning scientist with expertise in large-scale longitudinal data analysis with cutting edge statistical techniques.  This project represents the initial phase of a new type of study termed "Intervention Science."   Although interventions are relatively commonplace in educational settings, very little research has sought to comprehensively evaluate different interventions in a single, interdisciplinary methodological framework. The research plan seeks to understand the relative influence of different classroom "interventions" (e.g. "flipped" classes, active learning, peer assessment, etc.) on indicators of student success (e.g. course performance in downstream courses, participation in undergraduate research, conceptual learning gains, etc.). Construction of control and experimental groups will be accomplished using statistical techniques that assign students probabilistically to such categories. Confounding circumstances (e.g. students enrolled in different courses experiencing different interventions, or students interacting with peers in other courses) will be handled using techniques such as hierarchical linear modeling. Knowledge of the conditions in which instructional, cognitive-skill, and social/motivational interventions are most effective, and on whom, will inform the way in which faculty members implement effective interventions in the classroom and, in that way, have a significant impact on the educational experience of large numbers of STEM students nationwide.

por.por_cntn:
The University of Pittsburgh received an NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education: Education and Human Resources Design and Development tier award that brought together a highly interdisciplinary team to study a suite of promising instructional, cognitive-skill, and social/motivational interventions in the context of introductory STEM courses. Our goal was to understand which innovations and interventions produce long-term positive outcomes, whether these interventions combine negatively or synergistically within and across courses, and the types of situations or groups of students for which they are most effective.

The project team consisted of four Discipline-Based Education Research scientists, three learning scientists with expertise in social/motivational, cognitive skills or active STEM learning techniques, and a learning scientist with expertise in large-scale longitudinal data analysis with cutting edge statistical techniques. The project helped to train a cadre of research staff, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars in interdisciplinary research in the learning sciences. We created an IRB approved protocol and infrastructure to address the above research goals in the context of large, challenging introductory science classes at the University of Pittsburgh. This protocol provided access to de-identified data to perform comparative effectiveness studies (e.g., comparing two different sections of a class that are taught different ways to see if they have different long-term outcomes while controlling for relevant prior confounds such as prior grades and demographic variables). Further, the infrastructure enabled connecting this vast data set with other data collected in classrooms by instructors and departments such as tests, quizzes, homework, and motivational / attitude surveys vis-a-vis honest brokers who coordinate, connect, and de-identify the data sets.

We received multiple installments of “big data”, involving over N = 44,000 students over 13 years, through the protocol that we created and implemented. We tracked the learning and educational outcomes of a variety of instructional innovations / interventions across the four core disciplines of Biology, Chemistry, Physics, and Psychology. One aim of our work was to examine students’ motivation and attitudes across an array of class contexts to better understand the factors that affect STEM success. The surveys drew upon several motivational constructs including: interest, value, self-efficacy, theories of intelligence, belonging, science identity, and effects of peer interaction, among others. Furthermore, our aim was to examine individual differences in motivation for minoritized groups such as female students and students of color. For example, in physics we found large gender differences for several of the motivational factors. This work helped to identify important factors that educational innovations and interventions could impact and address to improve both short and long term learning and educational outcomes.

For example, we examined the impact of an ecological belonging intervention in both Biology and Physics classes. This intervention targets students’ uncertainty about belonging in a new academic environment. The intervention results were very promising with students who engaged in the activity showing better performance outcomes, attendance, and college retention one year later. Moreover, the intervention fostered equity as the benefits for the students were particularly pronounced for minoritized students.

This project has contributed to our understanding of the instructional, cognitive skill, and social-motivational interventions and factors within large enrollment introductory courses that significantly enhance long-term outcomes (e.g., later course performance) especially for at-risk students, and a methodology that enhances the rigor with which such work can be done throughout the University of Pittsburgh and replicated at other Universities.
